name: Southeast Asian History and Culture [3] Quiz | World | 10 Questions

questions.text: The world's nutmeg and cloves come mostly from which island(s)?
questions.explanation:
Moluccas.

	The Moluccas are thus called 'the spice islands'.

questions.text: Which kingdom ruled the core of modern Myanmar (Burma) from the 10th to the 13th centuries?
In which city can you find the Emerald Buddha?
questions.explanation:
Bangkok.

	Bangkok is, in fact, the 'City of the Emerald Buddha'.

questions.text: Which of the following kingdoms or empires did not rule all or part of modern Cambodia?
questions.explanation:
Srivijaya.

	The Srivijayan empire ruled in Sumatra and on the Malay peninsula.

questions.text: The mouth of the Chaophraya River is in which Southeast Asian country?
What Thai kingdom was founded in 1351 on the edge of the Khmer empire?
questions.explanation:
Ayudhya.

	The Thai ended up conquering the Khmer empire.

questions.text: The Vietnamese trace themselves back to a group of 15 tribal groups. What were these tribal groups called?
questions.explanation:
Lac Viet.

	These tribes came together to form a kingdom called Van-lang, which came to an end in the 3rd century B.C.

questions.text: By what derogatory term did the Chinese refer to Vietnam?
questions.explanation:
Annam.

	The term Annam, or 'pacified south', implied that the Vietnamese were a vassal state. Vietnam was indeed a vassal state of China for 1,000 years before the Vietnamese broke away from Chinese rule in the 10th century.

questions.text: Which of the following did not figure prominently in Vietnamese history?
questions.explanation:
Trinh Princes.

	The Hung Kings and Tayson Brothers both ruled Vietnam for a time and the Trung Sisters fought against Han Chinese rule. The Trinh Princes are fictional...as in, I just made them up.

questions.text: The great Hindu-Buddhist temple Borobudur can be found on what Indonesian island?
questions.explanation:
Java.

	For more on Borobudur look for my quiz entitled, strangely enough, 'Borobudur'.
